posts.name: Cody B.
posts.cooked:
Hey All, programming mentor here for Team 904

We did our very first swerve drive robot last year, and while it worked good enough, we are aiming a little higher this year. I have helped lead the kids down the path of using YAGSL , and I just a have a few questions, and hope to get pointed into the right direction.

When trying to strafe, the angle motors will oscillate, and eventually stop moving (not at the desired spot). I understand that this is probably just a PID issue. However, when trying to strafe, the drive motors will stop in place, and the wheels themselves will stop moving. Is there anyone who might have an understanding on what might be the issue here?

When trying to strafe, the angle motors will oscillate, and eventually stop moving (not at the desired spot). I understand that this is probably just a PID issue. However, when trying to strafe, the drive motors will stop in place, and the wheels themselves will stop moving. Is there anyone who might have an understanding on what might be the issue here?

I’m 90% positive I saw this being mentioned on the YAGSL website, but I can’t find it now, and I know this is a pretty common mistake with Swerve Drive. When trying to turn, the wheels will get angled inwards to make an X shape, rather than outwards to actually spin. If someone could please point me towards that on the website, or just help here, that would be appreciated.

I’m 90% positive I saw this being mentioned on the YAGSL website, but I can’t find it now, and I know this is a pretty common mistake with Swerve Drive. When trying to turn, the wheels will get angled inwards to make an X shape, rather than outwards to actually spin. If someone could please point me towards that on the website, or just help here, that would be appreciated.

What is the best way to find CANCoder offsets given the Pheonix 6 library does not support the 360degrees and uses rotations instead? Should we just convert those into degrees, or are we able to use rotations in the YAGSL swerve configuration?

What is the best way to find CANCoder offsets given the Pheonix 6 library does not support the 360degrees and uses rotations instead? Should we just convert those into degrees, or are we able to use rotations in the YAGSL swerve configuration?

This is likely a PID issue. Lower your P until it’s stable but still snappy.

This likely means your motors aren’t properly inverted, ensure you set the azimuth motors to be inverted.

You’re fine to convert from rotations. I don’t know if YAGSL supports rotations directly or not.

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked: For the angle offsets, you can read them directly from NetworkTables. Align the wheels forward with the gears to one side (we use the left). The start shuffleboard, connect to the robot (disabled) and find the entries like swerve/modules/frontleft There should be a raw absolute encode value, in degrees. That goes into the JSON file.

UPDATE! YAGSL is under active development so be sure to update it whenever you seee there is a new version, more likely than not it means there is a bugfix. This problem is something that happens in 2025.0.0 and is fixed in 2025.2.1

you did! Its here! Configuration | YAGSL

watch our new youtube series

And read these docs

It means you didn’t set your modules correctly

posts.name: Cody B.
posts.cooked:
THANK YOU ALL FOR THE HELP!!!

Just to recap what we had to do for any future eyes seeking the same knowledge, we inverted our angle motors in the JSON files for the modules, which seemed to fix our X-formation issue.

We lowered our PID , and the angle motors now go to the correct spot; both when strafing and rotating. I believe we also have to adjust that same (but different) PID for pathplanner still, but take that with a grain of salt, bc I’m not super positive. Will update on that later, once we get to doing it.

Also, we couldn’t find the CANCoder absolute encoder value in shuffleboard (we could, but it gave a string saying “number” instead of an actual number), so we just converted from rotations to degrees (rotations can be found in the Phoenix tuner app).

As for the drive motors not working when strafing, we just updated everything, and that seemed to fix the issue.

Heckboy:

it gave a string saying “number” instead of an actual numbe

For future reference, you can just drag that number in  and it will populate

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
There seems to be some confusion in the docs on this page .  Specifically the modules field says they should be “in order clockwise order starting from front left.”  However, the example at the bottom has them in a zig-zag order, not clockwise.

image 626×744 27 KB

image 626×744 27 KB

image 626×744 27 KB

Yeah i thought it was CCW but the order is sent to SwerveDriveKinematics . So follow whatever this page says.

declaration: package: edu.wpi.first.math.kinematics, class: SwerveDriveKinematics

Which i think is the Moore-Penrose pseudoinverse of [moduleLocations]

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
My recollection is that SwerveDriveKinematics doesn’t care what order you pass them in, as long as the modules are always passed in a consistent order every time you pass a list of modules or states.

nstrike:

Which i think is the Moore-Penrose pseudoinverse of [moduleLocations]

Dude… it’s a high school robotics competition, LOL.

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
I just meant the Description of the modules field in the docs should get updated so that it doesn’t conflict with the example right below it.

All the other examples I can find have it in the zig-zag order from that example.
I agree. What would you recommend i update the description too?
I would rather have the defined order until i know for sure the order doesn’t matter. So maybe “Module JSONs (fl,fr,bl,fr)”

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
nstrike:

Module JSONs (fl,fr,bl,fr)

You’ve got fr in there twice.

Those are very square/rectangular robot-centric.  There’s really nothing about a collection of swerve modules that should require they be in a rectangular configuration.  In 2023 our robot had 5 modules.

I intend to spend the next several decades of my life standing outside FIRST HQ petitioning to allow 5 drive motors again, because it opens up many interesting ideas for chassis shapes.

How about:

“Module JSONs (in the same order they’ll be returned as module states)”
